description: Core structural foundations of Canadian law. Covers jurisdiction, sources of authority, burden of proof, statutory interpretation basics, remedies, and procedural posture. Designed for high-level framework explanations, not legal advice.

topics.title: Jurisdiction (Federal vs Provincial Authority)
topics.coreDefinition: Jurisdiction determines which level of government or court has authority over a legal matter. In Canada, powers are divided between federal and provincial governments under the Constitution Act, 1867.
frameworkSteps: Identify subject matter (criminal, property, employment, contracts, immigration, etc.).
Determine whether authority flows from federal or provincial legislation.
Confirm which court or tribunal has subject-matter jurisdiction.
quickExamples: Property and civil rights are primarily provincial.
commonMistakes: Assuming federal law applies to all matters.

topics.title: Sources of Law in Canada
topics.coreDefinition: Canadian law derives from constitutional law, statutes and regulations, and case law. Secondary sources interpret but do not bind.
frameworkSteps: Check constitutional provisions if rights or division of powers are involved.
Locate relevant statute and regulations.
Identify leading cases interpreting the statute.
Consult secondary sources for context.
quickExamples: Charter rights questions begin with constitutional analysis.
Employment disputes often begin with provincial statutes.

intentSignals: where does this law come from

topics.title: Burden and Standard of Proof
topics.coreDefinition: The burden of proof determines who must prove a claim. The standard of proof determines how convincing that proof must be.
frameworkSteps: Identify which party bears the burden.
Determine applicable standard (balance of probabilities or beyond a reasonable doubt).
Assess whether evidence meets threshold.
quickExamples: Civil cases use balance of probabilities.
Criminal cases require proof beyond a reasonable doubt.

intentSignals: what do they need to prove

topics.title: Statutory Interpretation (Modern Principle)
topics.coreDefinition: Statutes are interpreted according to the modern principle: words are read in their entire context and in their grammatical and ordinary sense harmoniously with the scheme and object of the Act.
frameworkSteps: Read text in ordinary grammatical sense.
Consider broader statutory context.
Review legislative purpose.
Consult case law interpreting similar provisions.
quickExamples: A word may have ordinary meaning unless context indicates otherwise.
Purpose of consumer protection legislation may favor consumer interpretation.
commonMistakes: Isolating a single word without context.

topics.title: Legal Remedies
topics.coreDefinition: Remedies are legal responses to wrongdoing. They may be monetary (damages) or equitable (injunctions, specific performance).
frameworkSteps: Identify legal wrong or breach.
Determine appropriate category of remedy.
Assess limitations (mitigation, causation, foreseeability).
commonMistakes: Assuming all breaches result in large damages.

topics.title: Procedural Posture
topics.coreDefinition: Procedural posture refers to the stage and procedural context of a case (trial, appeal, motion).
frameworkSteps: Identify current stage (trial, appeal, summary judgment).
Determine applicable procedural rules.
Clarify what issues are preserved for review.
quickExamples: Summary judgment may resolve cases without trial.
commonMistakes: Confusing trial facts with appellate review standards.

notes: This pack supports structural explanations across most legal domains.
Always require jurisdiction clarification when uncertainty exists.
Designed for framework-level educational guidance, not case-specific advice.
